text: In his background, I would say, of course, we love back to Sid Campbell's. I mean, it's the kind of bread and butter of any good quant. And the more historical data, the better, typically. If you think about all those papers, like 100 years of trend following, that's a very comforting place for a quant to be. But going back to some of the discussion we had earlier, there's an inherent tension in that the ideas that have the most robust empirical support probably are also at the most risk of being commoditized. And that perhaps the concepts that have the greatest opportunities are those that can't be validated across long backtests and across a broad set of markets. So a couple of years ago, I kind of gave the research team a challenge to think about those areas that might still fit within a systematic framework, but that would challenge us in terms of our ability to backtest. It might be an emergent phenomenon. It might be something episodic or contextual in markets that just don't fit in that standard box. Just to be clear, these models don't represent... There's not a major allocation of our portfolios today. They're a relatively small allocation in aggregate. Something like the COVID model came in and then went out once that kind of period had passed. But it's my view that we need to be open to incorporating these kinds of ideas and to continue to push the boundaries of the traditional quant comfort zone. So how do we tackle these ideas? First of all, I think in most cases, you're going to have to rely more heavily on the investment thesis to start. So you need a clear criteria or set of criteria for when that thesis is going to be used. And I think that's a really important thing to think about. And I think that's a really important thing to think about. So you need to look at the model and the way that the model is in play, and also when it might no longer be valid. So when you might need to remove the model. And you also need to look for ways to validate the thesis, even if you don't have a long backtest. One way to think about this is that you might be able to find other empirical tests that you can do that wouldn't involve the predictive relationship. Predictive relationships, for what we're looking at, tend to be pretty noisy, which is why you need a lot of data to find some kind of statistical confidence. But often, the contemporaneous relationship may be stronger. And so you need to look for ways to validate the thesis, even if you don't have a long backtest. And so you might be able to use the contemporaneous relationship not to establish a profitable trade, but to just test something about the thesis. Is there something in play there or a relationship that's meaningful? So that's the kind of thing that we would look at. Think about the thesis. Think about more creative ways to test the thesis. And then also just think about what would it take to implement that strategy in live trading? Something like COVID epidemiology data would mean we would need to work with the data engineering team to think about can we scrape the data? And then also, what would it take to implement that strategy in live trading? And so we need to think about how to monitor that model to decide when the conditions have changed and when it's time to pull it.
